trans-unit.source: Configure Expressroute and Site-to-Site VPN connections that can coexist | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Configure Expressroute and Site-to-Site VPN connections that can coexist | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: This tutorial walks you through configuring ExpressRoute and a Site-to-Site VPN connection that can coexist.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial walks you through configuring ExpressRoute and a Site-to-Site VPN connection that can coexist.

trans-unit.source: Configure Azure ExpressRoute and Site-to-Site VPN connections that coexist
trans-unit.target: Configure Azure ExpressRoute and Site-to-Site VPN connections that coexist

trans-unit.source: You can now connect ExpressRoute and Site-to-Site VPN to the same virtual network.
trans-unit.target: You can now connect ExpressRoute and Site-to-Site VPN to the same virtual network.

trans-unit.source: There are two different scenarios and two different configuration procedures to choose from.
trans-unit.target: There are two different scenarios and two different configuration procedures to choose from.

trans-unit.source: Scenarios
trans-unit.target: Scenarios

trans-unit.source: Scenario 1
trans-unit.target: Scenario 1

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, you have one local network.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, you have one local network.

trans-unit.source: ExpressRoute is the active link, and your Site-to-Site VPN is the backup.
trans-unit.target: ExpressRoute is the active link, and your Site-to-Site VPN is the backup.

trans-unit.source: If the ExpressRoute connection fails, the Site-to-Site VPN connection would then become active.
trans-unit.target: If the ExpressRoute connection fails, the Site-to-Site VPN connection would then become active.

trans-unit.source: This scenario is most appropriate for high availability.
trans-unit.target: This scenario is most appropriate for high availability.

trans-unit.source: Coexist
trans-unit.target: Coexist

trans-unit.source: Scenario 2
trans-unit.target: Scenario 2

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, you have two local networks.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, you have two local networks.

trans-unit.source: You can connect one to Azure via ExpressRoute, and the other via Site-to-Site VPN.
trans-unit.target: You can connect one to Azure via ExpressRoute, and the other via Site-to-Site VPN.

trans-unit.source: In this case, both connections are active at the same time.
trans-unit.target: In this case, both connections are active at the same time.

trans-unit.source: Coexist
trans-unit.target: Coexist

trans-unit.source: Creating and configuring
trans-unit.target: Creating and configuring

trans-unit.source: There are two different sets of procedures to choose from in order to configure your connections to coexist.
trans-unit.target: There are two different sets of procedures to choose from in order to configure your connections to coexist.

trans-unit.source: The configuration procedure that you select will depend on whether you have an existing virtual network that you want to connect to, or you want to create a new virtual network.
trans-unit.target: The configuration procedure that you select will depend on whether you have an existing virtual network that you want to connect to, or you want to create a new virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Create a new virtual network and connections that coexist:
trans-unit.target: Create a new virtual network and connections that coexist:

trans-unit.source: If you don’t already have a virtual network, this procedure will walk you through creating a new virtual network and creating new ExpressRoute and Site-to-Site VPN connections.
trans-unit.target: If you don’t already have a virtual network, this procedure will walk you through creating a new virtual network and creating new ExpressRoute and Site-to-Site VPN connections.

trans-unit.source: To configure, follow the steps to [Create a new virtual network and connections](#create-a-new-virtual-network-and-connections-that-coexist).
trans-unit.target: To configure, follow the steps to [Create a new virtual network and connections](#create-a-new-virtual-network-and-connections-that-coexist).

trans-unit.source: Configure your existing virtual network for coexisting connections:
trans-unit.target: Configure your existing virtual network for coexisting connections:

trans-unit.source: You may already have a virtual network in place with an existing Site-to-Site VPN connection or ExpressRoute connection.
trans-unit.target: You may already have a virtual network in place with an existing Site-to-Site VPN connection or ExpressRoute connection.

trans-unit.source: The [Configure connections that coexist for your existing virtual network](#configure-connections-that-coexist-for-your-existing-virtual-network) procedure will walk you through deleting the gateway, and then creating new ExpressRoute and Site-to-Site VPN connections.
trans-unit.target: The [Configure connections that coexist for your existing virtual network](#configure-connections-that-coexist-for-your-existing-virtual-network) procedure will walk you through deleting the gateway, and then creating new ExpressRoute and Site-to-Site VPN connections.

trans-unit.source: Note that when creating the new connections, the steps must be completed in a very specific order.
trans-unit.target: Note that when creating the new connections, the steps must be completed in a very specific order.

trans-unit.source: Don't use the instructions in other articles to create your gateways and connections.
trans-unit.target: Don't use the instructions in other articles to create your gateways and connections.

trans-unit.source: In this procedure, creating connections that can coexist will require you to delete your gateway, and then configure new gateways.
trans-unit.target: In this procedure, creating connections that can coexist will require you to delete your gateway, and then configure new gateways.

trans-unit.source: This means you will have downtime for your cross-premises connections while you delete and recreate your gateway and connections, but you will not need to migrate any of your VMs or services to a new virtual network.
trans-unit.target: This means you will have downtime for your cross-premises connections while you delete and recreate your gateway and connections, but you will not need to migrate any of your VMs or services to a new virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Your VMs and services would still be able to communicate out through the load balancer while you configure your gateway if they are configured to do so.
trans-unit.target: Your VMs and services would still be able to communicate out through the load balancer while you configure your gateway if they are configured to do so.

trans-unit.source: Notes and limitations
trans-unit.target: Notes and limitations

trans-unit.source: You won’t be able to route (via Azure) between your local network connected via Site-to-Site VPN and your local network connected via ExpressRoute.
trans-unit.target: You won’t be able to route (via Azure) between your local network connected via Site-to-Site VPN and your local network connected via ExpressRoute.

trans-unit.source: You can't enable Point-to-Site VPN connections to the same VNet that is connected to ExpressRoute.
trans-unit.target: You can't enable Point-to-Site VPN connections to the same VNet that is connected to ExpressRoute.

trans-unit.source: Point-to-Site VPN and ExpressRoute cannot coexist for the same VNet.
trans-unit.target: Point-to-Site VPN and ExpressRoute cannot coexist for the same VNet.

trans-unit.source: Both the ExpressRoute gateway and the Site-to-Site VPN gateway must be either a Standard or HighPerformance gateway SKU.
trans-unit.target: Both the ExpressRoute gateway and the Site-to-Site VPN gateway must be either a Standard or HighPerformance gateway SKU.

trans-unit.source: For information about gateway SKUs, see [Gateway SKUs](../vpn-gateway/vpn-gateway-about-vpngateways.md).
trans-unit.target: For information about gateway SKUs, see [Gateway SKUs](../vpn-gateway/vpn-gateway-about-vpngateways.md).

trans-unit.source: If your local network is connected to both ExpressRoute and a Site-to-Site VPN (Scenario 1), you should have a static route configured in your local network to route the Site-to-Site VPN connection to the public Internet.
trans-unit.target: If your local network is connected to both ExpressRoute and a Site-to-Site VPN (Scenario 1), you should have a static route configured in your local network to route the Site-to-Site VPN connection to the public Internet.

trans-unit.source: You must create the ExpressRoute gateway first, before you add the Site-to-Site VPN gateway.
trans-unit.target: You must create the ExpressRoute gateway first, before you add the Site-to-Site VPN gateway.

trans-unit.source: Both procedures assume that you already have an ExpressRoute circuit configured.
trans-unit.target: Both procedures assume that you already have an ExpressRoute circuit configured.

trans-unit.source: If you do not, please see the following articles:
trans-unit.target: If you do not, please see the following articles:

trans-unit.source: Configure an ExpressRoute connection through a network service provider (NSP)
trans-unit.target: Configure an ExpressRoute connection through a network service provider (NSP)

trans-unit.source: Configure an ExpressRoute connection through an exchange provider (EXP)
trans-unit.target: Configure an ExpressRoute connection through an exchange provider (EXP)

trans-unit.source: Create a new virtual network and connections that coexist
trans-unit.target: Create a new virtual network and connections that coexist

trans-unit.source: This procedure will walk you through creating a virtual network, as well as creating Site-to-Site and ExpressRoute connections that will coexist.
trans-unit.target: This procedure will walk you through creating a virtual network, as well as creating Site-to-Site and ExpressRoute connections that will coexist.

trans-unit.source: Verify that you have the latest version of the PowerShell cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: Verify that you have the latest version of the PowerShell cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: You can download and install the latest PowerShell cmdlets from the PowerShell section of the [Download page](http://azure.microsoft.com/downloads/).
trans-unit.target: You can download and install the latest PowerShell cmdlets from the PowerShell section of the [Download page](http://azure.microsoft.com/downloads/).

trans-unit.source: Create a schema for your virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Create a schema for your virtual network.

trans-unit.source: For more information about working with the network configuration file, see [Configure a virtual network using a network configuration file](../virtual-network/virtual-networks-using-network-configuration-file.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about working with the network configuration file, see [Configure a virtual network using a network configuration file](../virtual-network/virtual-networks-using-network-configuration-file.md).

trans-unit.source: For more information about the configuration schema, see [Azure Virtual Network Configuration Schema](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/jj157100.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about the configuration schema, see [Azure Virtual Network Configuration Schema](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/jj157100.aspx).

trans-unit.source: When you create your schema, make sure you use the following values:
trans-unit.target: When you create your schema, make sure you use the following values:

trans-unit.source: The gateway subnet for the virtual network must be /27 (or a shorter prefix).
trans-unit.target: The gateway subnet for the virtual network must be /27 (or a shorter prefix).

trans-unit.source: The gateway connection type is "Dedicated".
trans-unit.target: The gateway connection type is "Dedicated".

trans-unit.source: After creating and configuring your xml schema file, upload the file.
trans-unit.target: After creating and configuring your xml schema file, upload the file.

trans-unit.source: This will create your virtual network.
trans-unit.target: This will create your virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Use the following cmdlet to upload your file, replacing the value with your own.
trans-unit.target: Use the following cmdlet to upload your file, replacing the value with your own.

trans-unit.source: Create an ExpressRoute gateway.
trans-unit.target: Create an ExpressRoute gateway.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to specify the GatewaySKU as *Standard* or *HighPerformance* and the GatewayType as *DynamicRouting*.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to specify the GatewaySKU as *Standard* or *HighPerformance* and the GatewayType as *DynamicRouting*.

trans-unit.source: Use the following sample, substituting the values for your own.
trans-unit.target: Use the following sample, substituting the values for your own.

trans-unit.source: Link the ExpressRoute gateway to the ExpressRoute circuit.
trans-unit.target: Link the ExpressRoute gateway to the ExpressRoute circuit.

trans-unit.source: After this step has been completed, the connection between your on-premises network and Azure, through ExpressRoute, is established.
trans-unit.target: After this step has been completed, the connection between your on-premises network and Azure, through ExpressRoute, is established.

trans-unit.source: Next, create your Site-to-Site VPN gateway.
trans-unit.target: Next, create your Site-to-Site VPN gateway.

trans-unit.source: The GatewaySKU must be *Standard* or *HighPerformance* and the GatewayType must be *DynamicRouting*.
trans-unit.target: The GatewaySKU must be *Standard* or *HighPerformance* and the GatewayType must be *DynamicRouting*.

trans-unit.source: To retrieve the virtual network gateway settings, including the gateway ID and the public IP, use the `Get-AzureVirtualNetworkGateway` cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To retrieve the virtual network gateway settings, including the gateway ID and the public IP, use the `Get-AzureVirtualNetworkGateway` cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Create a local site VPN gateway entity.
trans-unit.target: Create a local site VPN gateway entity.

trans-unit.source: This command doesn’t configure your on-premises VPN gateway.
trans-unit.target: This command doesn’t configure your on-premises VPN gateway.

trans-unit.source: Rather, it allows you to provide the local gateway settings, such as the public IP and the on-premises address space, so that the Azure VPN gateway can connect to it.
trans-unit.target: Rather, it allows you to provide the local gateway settings, such as the public IP and the on-premises address space, so that the Azure VPN gateway can connect to it.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] The local site for the site-to-site VPN is not defined in the netcfg.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.IMPORTANT] The local site for the site-to-site VPN is not defined in the netcfg.

trans-unit.source: Instead, you must use this cmdlet to specify the local site parameters.
trans-unit.target: Instead, you must use this cmdlet to specify the local site parameters.

trans-unit.source: You cannot define it using the Management Portal or the netcfg file.
trans-unit.target: You cannot define it using the Management Portal or the netcfg file.

trans-unit.source: Use the following sample, replacing the values with your own.
trans-unit.target: Use the following sample, replacing the values with your own.

trans-unit.source: To retrieve the virtual network gateway settings, including the gateway ID and the public IP, use the `Get-AzureVirtualNetworkGateway` cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To retrieve the virtual network gateway settings, including the gateway ID and the public IP, use the `Get-AzureVirtualNetworkGateway` cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: See the following example.
trans-unit.target: See the following example.

trans-unit.source: Configure your local VPN device to connect to the new gateway.
trans-unit.target: Configure your local VPN device to connect to the new gateway.

trans-unit.source: Use the information that you retrieved in step 6 when configuring your VPN device.
trans-unit.target: Use the information that you retrieved in step 6 when configuring your VPN device.

trans-unit.source: For more information about VPN device configuration, see [VPN Device Configuration](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=615099).
trans-unit.target: For more information about VPN device configuration, see [VPN Device Configuration](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=615099).

trans-unit.source: Link the Site-to-Site VPN gateway on Azure to the local gateway.
trans-unit.target: Link the Site-to-Site VPN gateway on Azure to the local gateway.

trans-unit.source: In this example, connectedEntityId is the local gateway ID, which you can find by running `Get-AzureLocalNetworkGateway`.
trans-unit.target: In this example, connectedEntityId is the local gateway ID, which you can find by running `Get-AzureLocalNetworkGateway`.

trans-unit.source: You can find virtualNetworkGatewayId by using the `Get-AzureVirtualNetworkGateway` cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You can find virtualNetworkGatewayId by using the `Get-AzureVirtualNetworkGateway` cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: After this step, the connection between your local network and Azure via the Site-to-Site VPN connection is established.
trans-unit.target: After this step, the connection between your local network and Azure via the Site-to-Site VPN connection is established.

trans-unit.source: Configure connections that coexist for your existing virtual network
trans-unit.target: Configure connections that coexist for your existing virtual network

trans-unit.source: If you have an existing virtual network connected via either ExpressRoute or Site-to-Site VPN connection, in order to enable both connections to connect to the existing virtual network, you must first delete the existing gateway.
trans-unit.target: If you have an existing virtual network connected via either ExpressRoute or Site-to-Site VPN connection, in order to enable both connections to connect to the existing virtual network, you must first delete the existing gateway.

trans-unit.source: This means your local premises will lose the connection to your virtual network over the gateway while you are working on this configuration.
trans-unit.target: This means your local premises will lose the connection to your virtual network over the gateway while you are working on this configuration.

trans-unit.source: **Before you begin configuration:** Verify that you have enough IP addresses left in your virtual network so that you can increase the gateway subnet size.
trans-unit.target: **Before you begin configuration:** Verify that you have enough IP addresses left in your virtual network so that you can increase the gateway subnet size.

trans-unit.source: Download the latest version of the PowerShell cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: Download the latest version of the PowerShell cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: You can download and install the latest PowerShell cmdlets from the PowerShell section of the [Download page](http://azure.microsoft.com/downloads/).
trans-unit.target: You can download and install the latest PowerShell cmdlets from the PowerShell section of the [Download page](http://azure.microsoft.com/downloads/).

trans-unit.source: Delete the existing Site-to-Site VPN gateway.
trans-unit.target: Delete the existing Site-to-Site VPN gateway.

trans-unit.source: Use the following cmdlet, replacing the values with your own.
trans-unit.target: Use the following cmdlet, replacing the values with your own.

trans-unit.source: Export the virtual network schema.
trans-unit.target: Export the virtual network schema.

trans-unit.source: Use the following PowerShell cmdlet, replacing the values with your own.
trans-unit.target: Use the following PowerShell cmdlet, replacing the values with your own.

trans-unit.source: Edit the network configuration file schema so that the gateway subnet is /27 (or a shorter prefix).
trans-unit.target: Edit the network configuration file schema so that the gateway subnet is /27 (or a shorter prefix).

trans-unit.source: See the following example.
trans-unit.target: See the following example.

trans-unit.source: For more information about working with the network configuration file, see [Configure a Virtual Network using a network configuration file](../virtual-network/virtual-networks-using-network-configuration-file.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about working with the network configuration file, see [Configure a Virtual Network using a network configuration file](../virtual-network/virtual-networks-using-network-configuration-file.md).

trans-unit.source: For more information about the configuration schema, see [Azure Virtual Network Configuration Schema](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/jj157100.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about the configuration schema, see [Azure Virtual Network Configuration Schema](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/jj157100.aspx).

trans-unit.source: If your previous gateway was a Site-to-Site VPN, you must also change the connection type to **Dedicated**.
trans-unit.target: If your previous gateway was a Site-to-Site VPN, you must also change the connection type to **Dedicated**.

trans-unit.source: At this point, you'll have a VNet with no gateways.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you'll have a VNet with no gateways.

trans-unit.source: You can proceed with **Step 3** in the article, [Create a new virtual network and connections](#create-a-new-virtual-network-and-connections-that-coexist), in order to create new gateways and complete your connections.
trans-unit.target: You can proceed with **Step 3** in the article, [Create a new virtual network and connections](#create-a-new-virtual-network-and-connections-that-coexist), in order to create new gateways and complete your connections.

trans-unit.target: Learn more about ExpressRoute.

trans-unit.target: See the [ExpressRoute overview](expressroute-introduction.md).

trans-unit.target: Learn more about VPN Gateways.
